message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Romanized terms kill the philosophical experiment">
The author raises a critical point about the "philosophical experiment" argument:

If we romanize everything — Dao, De, Ren, Yi, Li — then the passage has NO English semantic content for the Western reader. The reader encounters five opaque foreign terms in a sequence. The "philosophical experiment" (where the reader first accepts a conventional understanding, then watches it get deconstructed) CANNOT work, because the reader never had a conventional understanding to begin with. The romanized terms have very few morphisms in their Jing — they are semantically empty for the English reader.

The experiment requires the reader to FEEL something when they read "virtue," "humaneness," "righteousness" — to bring their own associations — and THEN experience the reversal. If they just see "De, Ren, Yi, Li," they have nothing to reverse. The passage becomes an abstract report about foreign concepts rather than a lived philosophical experience.

Does this change your thinking? Should we use English translations (the Way, virtue, humaneness, rightness, ritual conduct) in the block quote precisely SO the philosophical experiment works on the English reader?

Reconsider. Brief response.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
The author is right. I was wrong. This is a decisive argument.

The entire epistemological structure of the passage depends on the reader having semantic content to work with. You can't deconstruct what was never constructed. If the reader sees "De, Ren, Yi, Li," those are empty tokens — there's nothing to grip, nothing to reverse, nothing to feel the loss of. The philosophical experiment requires loaded English words precisely because the loading is what gets disrupted.

Use full English translations in the block quote: "the Way," "virtue," "humaneness," "rightness," "ritual conduct." Let the reader bring their Western associations. Then when the author's analysis begins dismantling those associations — when "virtue" becomes "constitutive character" and the reader feels the ground shift — THAT is the experiment working.

The gloss format still applies: "the Way (道, dao)," "virtue (德, de)," etc. The Chinese characters and pinyin are there for scholarly reference. But the English does the philosophical work.

I retract my previous answer on Dao. "The Way (道, dao)" is correct for the block quote.
input.summary: Author is right — full English needed for experiment to work
